entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued June 25 at 1:37PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...POTENTIAL FLOODING OF AREA RIVERS DUE TO ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES... Very warm temperatures are expected to increase through this weekend and persist through mid next week. These near record high temperatures will increase snow and ice melt and subsequent water-levels of area rivers including the Chilkat, Klehini, and
entry.cap:areaDesc: Haines Borough and Lynn Canal; Taiya Inlet and Klondike Highway

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 25 at 5:48AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAT WAVE NEXT WEEK... Temperatures soar late this weekend and remain high into mid next week across the northern and central Inner Channels. A few temperature records could fall. The warmest days are expected to be Monday into Wednesday when temperatures swell well into the 80s. Conditions could feel muggy at times as well. With around 18
entry.cap:areaDesc: Haines Borough and Lynn Canal; Juneau Borough and Northern Admiralty Island; Taiya Inlet and Klondike Highway

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 25 at 5:48AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...VERY WARM NEXT WEEK... Temperatures will soar this weekend with highs up to 75 to 85 degrees. The warmest days are expected to be Monday through Wednesday, although for the southern Panhandle including Ketchikan and Metlakatla, the warmest days will likely be Sunday through Tuesday. A few temperature records could fall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Baranof Island and Southern Admiralty Island; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Inner Channels from Kupreanof Island to Etolin Island; Southern Inner Channels

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 25 at 5:48AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAT WAVE NEXT WEEK... Temperatures soar this weekend and remain high well into mid next week in Hyder. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 26 at 1:21AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...PATCHY DENSE FOG NEAR LAKE MICHIGAN EARLY THIS MORNING... Look for patchy dense fog near Lake Michigan during the early morning hours across Door, Kewaunee, and Manitowoc counties. The fog will be locally dense, with visibilities as low as one quarter of a mile possible at times. The fog is expected to dissipate later this morning as gusty west winds push the fog offshore
